data.title: Fix highlight end pixel position calculation
data.body: Previously, we were calculating the position preceding block decorations for the row following the end of the highlighted range, but that's actually wrong. We just want the position following block decorations of the end of the highlighted range, plus one line height. This prevents us from incorrectly rendering the end of highlight after block decorations that immediately follow the end of the highlighted range. Before: After: /cc @ungb @as-cii

data.title: Ctrl-9 not recognized on macOS 10.12
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The keyboard shortcuts ctrl-6, ctrl-7, ctrl-8 and ctrl-9 are not recognized.  By this I mean: I use `cmd-.` to invoke the keybinding resolver.  I hit some keyboard combination, say ctrl-1.  When I press ctrl, the keybindig resolver shows me "ctrl".  When I then hit the 1 key, the display changes from just "ctrl" to "ctrl-1", and underneath the key name, it shows me which command would be executed.

But when I hit ctrl-6, ctrl-7, ctrl-8 or ctrl-9, the keybinding resolver shows me just "ctrl" and never shows me the additional digit.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Start Atom
2. Invoke keybinding resolver with `cmd-.`
3. Press and then release the `ctrl` key.  Remember what the keybinding resolver shows.
4. Press `ctrl-5`.  Remember what the keybinding resolver shows.
5. Press `ctrl-9`.  Remember what the keybinding resolver shows.

**Expected behavior:** What the keybinding resolver shows after steps 3, 4, 5 should be different.  What it shows after step 4 and after step 5 should be somehow similar.

**Actual behavior:** What the keybinding resolver shows after step 3 and after step 5 is _exactly_ the same.  By this I mean that if you were to take screenshots of the Atom window after these steps, they would be identical, pixel for pixel.

**Reproduces how often:** Always.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.14.1

I'm running macOS Sierra 10.12.6..

### Additional Information

Actually, I wanted to complain that keybindings don't work in the github package, until I found out that it's actually the `ctrl-9` keybinding that doesn't give focus to the git tab.  If I invoke the command to focus the git tab from the palette, then I can use keybindings such as cursor up and cursor down.

It occurs to me that macOS might be stealing the keybinding, so I opened System Preferences and did some spelunking in the Keyboard / Shortcuts portion.  I went through all of "Launchpad & Dock", "Mission Control", "Keyboard", "Input Sources", "Screen Shots", "Services", "Spotlight", "Accessibility", "App Shortcuts".  The result is that `ctrl-6` through `ctrl-9` are not mentioned in any of these places.

It occurs to me that FastScripts might be stealing the keybinding, but I don't use these keys there, either.

It's not BetterTouchTool, either.

The activation key for ShortCat is `cmd-shift-space`, so that's not it, either.

I temporarily quit HammerSpoon to make sure that's not the culprit, either.

The only key configured in Bartender is `option-f12`, so that's not it, either.

I think you can tell I'm a keyboard fetishist...

data.title: Drop use of GPU tiles for lines and line numbers
Async watchPath method
data.body:
Rather than synchronously returning a `PathWatcher` from the `watchPath` method and requiring users to await the `getStartPromise()` manually in test cases to avoid flaky tests, return a `Promise` that resolves to the `PathWatcher` after it's started.

I originally did it the other way for efficiency, but it's much harder to reason about, and accessing the start Promise in tests is often challenging. As evidence of this, it's the root cause of the flaky GitHub package test we're seeing in the atom/atom build right now... which _I_ wrote, against my own API üòá 

Along the way, I also fixed a subtle timing bug related to the event timing during the NativeWatcher re-attachment sequence when watchers are split or joined, and introduced a private `printWatchers()` method that's useful as a sanity check on the watchers that are alive at any given moment.

/cc @damieng as the only other current consumer of this API. If you're writing any tests that exercise `atom.project.onDidChangeFiles`, you'll need to await `atom.project.getWatcherPromise(projectPath)` before manipulating the filesystem and expecting the watcher to pick it up. I'd be happy to send PRs to fix any specs up myself if you point me to a repo that needs it.

/cc @nathansobo because this _should_ fix that GitHub package test flake you noticed yesterday.

/cc @maxbrunsfeld because this was his original suggestion and I should have listened to him to begin with :wink:

Remaining work: update the GitHub package to await the result of `watchPath`.

### Description

Syntax assigned to unsaved buffers is not preserved when restarting Atom.

I do a lot of work that involves editing HTML fragments, often from locations that either aren't directly editable or have no syntax highlighting. I will usually copy this into Atom, make the necessary changes, and paste it back. This provides a lot more than just syntax highlighting, such as auto-complete and auto-indent. ### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom and add a project root
2. Open a new tab and add some content in a defined language, e.g. HTML or Python
3. Assign the correct syntax to the buffer
3. Do not save the content to a file
4. Restart Atom

**Expected behavior:** Atom re-opens with everything - content, settings, etc - preserved

**Actual behavior:** Atom re-opens with syntax set to plain text on unsaved buffers

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time, every time

### Versions

1.17.2 when I first started using Atom, currently on 1.19.2 ia32 and this behaviour has always been consistent. OS is 64-bit Windows 10 Pro 15063.483 running on an i5-6400 with 8GB RAM.

data.title: Don't assign default path for `showSaveDialog` unless it exists
data.body:
Fixes #14732

Problem: "Save As" for a new file would default to the previously used directory, instead of the open project folder in Atom. 

A regression was introduced where we were assigning the default path to be `undefined` when there was no file path for an item, as in the case of a brand new, unsaved file. When no default path is specified the operating system defaults to displaying the previously used directory.

The fix was to simply not set the default path in `Pane.prototype.saveItemAs` if the item has no path, and let `AtomWindow.prototype.showSaveDialog` set it based on the project paths, which happens later on down the code path.

data.title: Always round GPU layer dimensions to physical pixel boundaries
data.body:
Fixes #13361
Fixes #15180
Fixes #15257
Fixes #14237
Fixes #14898
Fixes #12652
Fixes #13627

This ensure subpixel anti-aliasing works when `window.devicePixelRatio` is not an integer. Since subpixel anti-aliasing relies on the physical characteristics of the display, Chromium only enables it when rasterizing content that it knows will be aligned to a physical pixel boundary.

@50Wliu @ungb @Ben3eeE: can you give this a spin on Windows, please? We have tested it works correctly with 125% on Windows and by manually calling `setZoomLevel` on macOS in the console, but we'd like to make sure this is a holistic solution to the blurriness problem. Also, if you think this fixes more issues than the ones we have linked above, feel free to add them.

/cc: @atom/maintainers 

üçê'd with @nathansobo.

data.title: Update.exe went rogue?
data.body: Last night, I was on Atom 1.19.1, Windows 10. Things started to go a bit weird. My Windows `System` process (NT kernel & system) started hogging ~30% of my CPU indefinitely, which I had no reason to believe was anything to do with Atom. However, this morning nothing happened when I tried to open Atom. I noticed 1.19.2 had appeared in my `%LOCALAPPDATA%/atom/` folder, but I could only open 1.19.1, and when I did, it opened without any packages/themes enabled. I tried deleting the 1.19.2 folder (which didn't go to completion as something was using one of the files). Then, Norton flagged up `Update.exe` as acting suspiciously. I let it quarantine `Update.exe`, and then my `System` process stopped hogging the CPU (this could be a coincidence, of course). Anyway, I then successfully deleted 1.19.2 folder, and then downloaded the installer from the atom homepage. Now everything's working fine, I'm on 1.19.2. Not sure what happened there, but I thought I'd open an issue in case anyone else suffers the same fate and comes googling.

data.title: Fix folding for lines that contain a comment
data.body:
Fixes #15308

In attempting to optimize the performance of `isFoldableAtBufferRow` in 3c87b74, we mistakenly introduced a bug that caused lines that contained a comment but didn't start with one to not be foldable anymore.

With this commit we are restoring the previous behavior, thus only disabling folding for lines that start with a comment (ignoring leading whitespaces).

/cc: @nathansobo @Ben3eeE @ungb

data.title: Closing an unsaved tab with middleclick on Linux prevents mouse clicks
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
* [ ] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
* [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
* [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
* [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When I close an __unsaved__ tab with __middle click__ on Ubuntu 16.04, the "This file has changes" popup appears and completely blocks my mouse clicks.  
I can't click on anything, not even the "Don't save" button.

I can, however, move to the "Cancel" button with the arrow keys and then close the popup with "Enter".  
As soon as the popup is closed, the problem disappears and I can click where I want.

Note that I don't have this bug when I close an unsaved tab with "Right click > Close tab" or a __saved__ tab with middle click.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a new Atom instance with `atom --safe`
2. Type "test" in the text editor, don't save.
3. Click on the tab with the middle mouse button

**Expected behavior:** A "This file has changes" popup appears, I __can__ close it by clicking on "Cancel".

**Actual behavior:** A "This file has changes" popup appears, I __can't__ click on it with my mouse.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

Atom    : 1.19.2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
```

### Additional Information

This is a very specific bug and I don't know if it comes from Atom or Ubuntu but I don't recall having this issue on Atom 1.18.

data.title: Ignore scroll requests to NaN, null or undefined positions
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15247

This was a guard we used to have in `TextEditorPresenter`, prior to the editor rendering layer rewrite:

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/b580ff8642d4401892c730f6bd2e1b38bd00b3e5/src/text-editor-presenter.coffee#L723-L732

With this pull-request we are adding those guard clauses back, preventing `NaN`, `null` or `undefined` values that were mistakenly passed to the `setScrollTop` or `setScrollLeft` APIs from putting the editor into an inconsistent state.

/cc: @nathansobo @Ben3eeE @ungb
